title.narrative: Decision Support System for Water Resources Planning
LWC TOR with BDS updated on 11 Sep 2013
NCE draft and WP 2011 DSS for Water Resources
Annual Progress Report 2013 GEF RE PPG 30 March
DSS annual report final draft 26 May 2011_LL_RD

description.narrative: The Ministry of Water Resources makes effective use of DSS as a comprehensive and effective tool in decision making, taking the various sectors into consideration.
independent political entity

1. User requirements for DSS clarified, Existing data identified and digitized into database, New data collected, DSS technical platform developed, Quality monitored and assessed and DSS deployed
2. User requirements for TIS clarified, Systems for TIS data collection developed, TIS technical platform developed, Quality monitored and assessed, TIS deployed
3. Technical capacity of MoWR staff built, Opportunities for lessons learning and exchange of experience provided, DSS and TIS incorporated into institutional structures, roles and work processes.
4. Buy-in and endorsement from all key stakeholders obtained, Capacity of decision-makers to interpret and use DSS information to inform decisions strengthened.

comment.narrative: The Iraqi government urgently needs to build its administrative and technical capacity to manage the country’s water resources and provide a sustainable response to the related environmental, economic and human development issues. This need has been recognized in the International Compact with Iraq in which the Iraqi Government adopted the goal to “Develop a consolidated land and water management policy and a comprehensive approach towards resolution of cross border water issues” as a means for developing “stable, competitive and sustainable agriculture to enhance food security and rural incomes, generate rural employment, diversify economic growth and protect the natural environment”

activity-description.narrative: The project location could be consider as Baghdad since all the governmental high level bodies (Parliament, Cabinet) are in Baghdad

description.narrative: Elections - elections

1) Strategic Plan for increased Parliament efficiency completed
2) Media strategy for COR implemented
3) Pilot Standard Operational Procedures for Committees drafted
4) Development of a legislation for the creation of the Commission on Women

comment.narrative:
1) No Strategic Plan for Parliament efficiency available. Media strategy for COR drafted
3) No Standard Operational Procedures for Committees in place
4) No legislation for a Commission on Women in place

New working tools (including work plans, SOPs and structures) of five directorates and the legal department are approved and put into action and 70% of staff involved in those departments perceives early signs of efficiency as a result. - Technical assistance and advanced training to CoR Research Department focusing on database management and social indicator analysis Draft work plans for five Directorates based on Review recommendations

-A draft performance evaluation system was proposed to the Secretariat, based on global best practice. It is anticipated that a final version of the performance evaluation mechanism will be completed during the third quarter of the project. -UNDP under this project supported the participation of the Iraqi Parliament in the Regional workshop, organized by UNDP Regional HUB and Tunisia Country Office on the role of the Parliament in strengthening decentralization.

description.narrative: The role of IGs is strengthened within their ministries and IGs and their staff demonstrate improved technical skills and capacity

participating-org.narrative: US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

provider-org.narrative: US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.
US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.

description.narrative: Output 1: The role of IGs is strengthened within their ministries. 1a. Institutional frameworks strengthened to comply with the approved Anti-Corruption Strategy in the areas of prevention, and improving the performance within respective ministries including minimizing wastage of public funds. 1b. Number of policies, strategies and action plans with indicators on code of conduct and corruption by respective ministries. 1d. Numbers of completed corruption risk assessments by respective ministries. Output 2: IGs and their staff demonstrate improved technical skills and capacity 2a. Sixty eight (68) technical training sessions conducted for technical staff. 2b. Training manual developed for new staff after project completion. 2c. Capacity developed through training of trainers with international certification on audit, inspection and administrative investigation in place. 2d. Forensic capacity assessed. Output 3: IT related skills enhanced 3a. Single portal in place with number of automated processes and reports identified. 3b. Number of software performance assessment tools available to IGs with challenges regarding technical assistance and implementation identified. 3c.Number of electronically disseminated benchmarks and good practice on anti-corruption legislation.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: The role of IGs is strengthened within their ministries. 1a. Institutional framework of the IG as an oversight body not in place with lack of clarity and practical arrangements between the IG and ministries. 1b. Current legal framework fails to provide for coordination or protocols between the IGs and ministries. 1d. Corruption risk assessments by ministries are not in place.
Output 2: IGs and their staff demonstrate improved technical skills and capacity 2a. IGs often face difficulty as they lack technical and policy tools. There are difficulties in attracting qualified candidates. 2b. Training manuals do not exist and structures not in place at initiation of the project. 2c. IG capacity gaps and training needs to accomplish their mandate can results in IGs taking a passive stance within the ministries, limiting the scope of their role and/or specific allegations.
Output 3: IT related skills enhanced 3a. Lack of automated processes. 3b. Software performance assessment tools are not available to IGs. 3c. Inability to electronically disseminate information on good practice or anti-corruption legislation.

1a. Developing of White Paper & Road Map for the OIGs. 1b. Completion of specific Standard operation Procedures (SOPs) for the OIGs in Iraq. 1c.A study on the feasibility of establishing a body for the OIGs developed. 1d.A study on the feasibility of establishing OIGs at the provincial level developed. 2a. Training in the areas of Administrative Investigation & Performance Evaluation for the OIGs Staff. 2b. 10 workshops to develop 5 Quality Standards for the OIGs in Iraq Output4 ( New activities replacing the remaining output3 activities ) 4a.Developing of 5 Quality Standards ( OIG General Quality Standard ; Auditing Quality Standard ; Inspection Quality Standard for the OIGs in Iraq ; Investigation Quality Standard ; Performance Evaluation Quality Standard). 4b. 10 workshops to develop 5 Quality Standards for the OIGs in Iraq.

1a. A white Paper and A Road Map have been achieved and approved by the IGs. 1b. 27 Specific Standard Operation Procedures (SOPs) have been developed for the OIGs in Iraq. 1c.A study on the feasibility of establishing a body for the OIGs developed have been developed 100%. 1d.A study on the feasibility of establishing OIGs at the provincial level developed have been developed 100%. 2a. Training in the areas of Administrative Investigation (11 training courses-324 employee from 34 OIGs) & Performance Evaluation (9 Training courses-285 employee from 33 OIGs).Total number of employees participated is 609. 2b. 10 workshops to develop 5 Quality Standards for the OIGs in Iraq have been conducted (5 Workshops on June 2015 & 5 Workshops on Sept.2015).
Output4 ( New activities replacing the remaining output3 activities ) 4a. 5 Quality Standards have been developed for the OIGs in Iraq ( OIG General Quality Standard ; Auditing Quality Standard ; Inspection Quality Standard; Investigation Quality Standard ; Performance Evaluation Quality Standard).

description.narrative:
This project aims for:
support the Government of Iraq’s efforts in creating a strategy to ensure that victims of domestic and gender based violence are offered refuge, reintegration and access to justice

title.narrative: P102 2013 Annual Narrative Report Family Support Justice and Security
P102 Family Protection Support Justice and Security Q2 2012 UNDAF TF 81968 UNDP 81992
P102 Family Protection Support Justice and Security Q1 Report 2012 UNDAF TF 81968

description.narrative: Support the Government of Iraq’s efforts in creating a strategy to ensure that victims of domestic and gender based violence are offered refuge, reintegration and access to justice
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: The Project is serving the entire country

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

1- 300 staff in FPUs are trained on how to address GBV and DV and victims of trafficking. 2- Policy drafted and submitted to address family protection and GBV for KRG and GOI endorsement. 3- 20 CSOs participating in a referral system at CSO level. 4- 15 NGOs providing legal aid services. 5- Shelter policy drafted.

comment.narrative: 1- No staff in FPUs are trained on how to address GBV and DV and victims of trafficking. 2- No policy exist to address Family protection and GBV. 3- No CSOs participate in a referral system at CSO level. 4- No NGOs provide legal aid services. 5- No shelter policy exist.

- 300 Family protection units staff trained on How to address violence against women and children and victims of trafficking - Policy to address Family Protection and GBV drafted. - 19 raising awareness campaigns on the legislations related to family protection - A study on violence against children completed - Child Protection Policy drafted - Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and Protocols. - Manuals for Family Protection developed - 300 police staff (disaggregated by Sex) in central government and KRG trained on the Family Protection Units standard operating procedures - 100 female police staff trained on how to respond to GBV and domestic violence - 10 Units of victim support units in Police stations in Baghdad established, and referral centres - 25 of CSO participating in the new Referral system at CSO level - A Coordination process to establish Linkages between the Family Protection Directorates and existing Monitoring and Reporting Mechanism for Grave Child Right’s Violations (MRM) referral mechanism in place - 250 Family protection units and directorates staff of disaggregated by sex) trained on how address to violence against women and children cases - Mapping and capacity assessment of NGOs providing legal aid to victoms of violence completed - 15 NGOs providing supported to provide legal aid services - 300 of NGOs staff trained on child protection issues - Five NGOs of CSOs involved in drafting of the Shelter Policy - drafting of shelter policy - Shelter policy reviewed and re-drafted in a participatory manner - 6 of advocacy initiatives undertaken

- 393 FPUs and DCVAWs staff, senior management and law enforcement officers, have been trained on GBV and DV. - Anti-domestic Violence Bill is endorsed and adopted in KRG. Draft Anti Domestic Violence is submitted for endorsement in at Federal level. - Strategic framework and action-plan for the FPUs at federal levels are endorsed and adopted. - Shelter policy is developed at federal and regional level adopted by MOLSA at federal and regional levels, - 4 MoUs signed between UNDP, KBA, DCVAW and IBA institutionalizing free legal aid services and establishing referral system. - Legal Assistance Law drafted and being submitted to Parliament in KR-I. - Intake- forms have been developed at federal and regional levels, endorsed and adopted by FPUs in Iraq. - Draft SOPs developed and adopted by FPUs. - MOUs signed between DCVAW and KBA have been signed to establish first institutionalized referral system between the two institutions. - Training materials have been developed - The Total of 126 Police officers have been trained (36 female and 90 male). Through the training units established within DCVAW additional trainings will be organized to reach the target by the end of the project. - The Total of 36 female police staff have been trained. The trained cadre will conduct trainings targeting female police officer. - 10 Units established in KRG. This target is on track. - 25 of CSO participating in the new Referral system at CSO level - 393 (176 female and 220 male) FPUs and DCVAWs staff, senior management and law enforcement officers, have been trained on GBV and DV. - 12 NGOs providing supported to provide legal aid services - Five NGOs of CSOs involved in drafting of the Shelter Policy at federal and regional level. - Shelter policy has been drafted in KRG and submitted for approval to MOLSA. - Draft Shelter strategy has been shared with federal government - Two High level meetings organized at federal and Regional level to discuss the Roadmap for the a

independent political entity

1. a A comprehensive needs assessment determining the Academy’s administrative, operational, financial and sustainable requirements completed. 1.b The Academy’s Organizational structure based on the needs assessment determined. 2a. Faculties and centres are established and equipped. 2b. Staffing levels, roles and responsibilities with clear TOR are identified. 3a. Appropriate staff employed, curricula, training courses and materials developed.

comment.narrative: 1.a No structure in place for Academy’s administrative, operational, financial and sustainable systems. 1.b Multiple gaps exist in the Academy’s organizational structure. 2a. Faculties and centres of excellence are not in place nor equipped. 2b. Roles and responsibilities not identified nor TORs. 3. Staff need to be employed and curricula, training courses and materials need to be developed.

title.narrative: Vocational Training MSME Capacity Development in Basra

description.narrative: The project aims to increase the number of local area development activities, promote local small and medium enterprises and provide vocational training to respond to the private sector’s needs.

82551 UNDP Shell ProDoc VTC and MSME Support

description.narrative: Outcome 1: Inclusive participatory processes in local area planning and decision making are institutionalized. Local communities are given a key role in influencing development priorities and in turn contribute to further stability and reconciliation
first-order administrative division
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

• Project Management Structure established • Harmonized Certification Standards and Licensing regime established • Vocational Training Institute concept and implementation option decided; 'Quick-Win' training component launched • Training Content and Delivery Programme designed • Multi-Stakeholder Alignment / Consultation Platform established • Labor Market Assessment conducted • Improved capacity of 43 contractors on identified skills gaps

comment.narrative:
Vocational Training Environment based on ad-hoc training efforts; disrepair to existing VTC infrastructure; lack of systematic approach; lack of certifications
Rudimentary support system for local MSMEs with no structured technical assistance opportunities. In particular, no opportunities for MSMEs to obtain certifications which are required by international companies in order to win contracts
1. Providing Capacity Building for Existing Shell Contractors 2. Follow up on WTTC project and other ideas for institutionalizing vocational training

1.1 Three NEBOSH Health and Safety at Work courses were conducted for 49 trainees. 1.2 NEBOSH International General Certificate in Occupational Health and Safety course was conducted for 12 trainees 1.3 Two English language courses were conducted for 36 trainees 2.1 Cooperation UNDP was agreed and strengthened with South Oil Company and Basra Oil Training Institute for organizational re-structuring

No Local Economic Assessment in Ninewa that tackles key sectors for strategic planning 1.5 Less than 5 governorate staff in KR who are aware of vulnerability assessment 1.6 Lack of Governorate capacity to execute projects and conduct M&E 1.7 No action plans for service providers to systematically improve service delivery. 1.8. Officials lack capacity in the principles of transparency and accountability. 1.9 Governorates do not consistently have information on local plans and budgets available to public 1.10 No governorate staff currently capable of using or utilizing KDMS as a planning and controlling tools for governorates’ projects 2.1 No Provincial Development Strategies for any of KR governorates 2.2 Three (3) governorates currently have Provincial Annual Plans for 2014 with LADP assistance in 2013 3.1 Governorates do not have systematic guidelines or a process for citizen participation and representation 3.2 No effective, systematic and regular citizen participation mechanisms in governorates 3.3 No involvement of CSO in the provincial planning process 3.4 No existing CSO networks classified under key sectors for governorates’ needs 3.5 Lack of capacity within the KRG NGO Directorate in Monitoring & Evaluation and no M&E system in place for its projects 3.6 KR DNGOs has weak capacity in managing its granting scheme, with no impact of responding to CSOs needs or KR strategic planning 3.7 Lack of capacity within CSOs to conduct vulnerability mapping 4.1 No official consideration in the governorates’ planning for gender and youth needs 4.2 No awareness of Gender responsive Budgeting at KR governorates 4.3 No clearly identified local stakeholders groups and think ta

description.narrative: Ani-Corruption component of Enhancing Transparent Participatory Governance and Human Rights Programme
independent political entity

1) Number of trainers deployed in the CoR Committees and in the Governorates. 2) Consultations conducted on the framework to establish the KRG Commission of Integrity. 3) Investigative journalism curriculum developed.

comment.narrative: 1) No (zero) CoR committees trained. 2) No consultantions in place to dicuss the establishment of the KRG Commission of Integrity. 3) No investigative journalism curriculum in place

The framework has four outputs focusing on strengthening human rights and transparency through participatory governance mechanisms. First, to support the mandate and organizational structure of the Human Rights Commission, including the establishment of sub-national commissions. Second, to provide long term institutional development of the Human Rights Commission and its outreach capabilities through participatory governance mechanisms. Third, combat corruption through the promotion of accountability, integrity and transparency at all levels of government and civil society. This involves support to the roll-out of the Government of Iraq’s National Anti-Corruption Strategy, to strengthen the capacities of key parliamentary committees, to address corruption issues, to enhance engagement of civil society organisations and media in addressing corruption and to provide technical support for the establishment of a new KRG Commission of Integrity and KRG Board of Supreme Audit. Fourth, to utilise civil society organisations to promote participatory and transparent governance which includes financial and technical support to civil society organisations to enhance their engagement with parliament.

UNDP has continued to provide technical advisory support to the establishment of the Human Rights Advisory Board. Through recruitment of a CSOs expert, 19 members have been nominated and voted for by CSOs to form the Governing Body of the Human Rights Advisory Board. An official launching of this mechanism will take place during the Q4 of the project period.

title.narrative: Developing Disaster Risk Management Capacities in Iraq

description.narrative: The Project has been developed to enable the different levels of Iraqi government and communities to reduce losses and damages from natural and human-induced disasters by adopting effective mitigation and preparedness approaches

participating-org.narrative: UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)

title.narrative: DRM ProDoc Final sign by CO
Developing Disaster Risk Management Capacities in Iraq
Developing Disaster Risk Management Capacities in Iraq
Developing Disaster Risk Management Capacities in Iraq
Developing Disaster Risk Management Capacities in Iraq

description.narrative: Establishing Disaster Risk reduction Policies and institutions, creating capacities for human resources development, through provision of High-quality advisory services.

participating-org.narrative: UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)

description.narrative: independent political entity

provider-org.narrative: UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)
UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)

description.narrative: Concept note for establishment of the national DRR center Organogram and ToR for key positions SOP for the national DRM centre Inception workshop report Training Module developed and training programme organized for relevant GOI Officials Guidance note prepared to facilitate the Web-portal design Disaster Information and Knowledge management strategy Focal Points established in the four sectoral ministries to deal with defined DRR actions Technical Note available to guide DRR mainstreaming into development sectors DRR Training Modules developed for capacity building on DRR DRR skills enhanced through training Focal persons established to lead DRR actions at the Governorate levels Roles and responsibilities for DRR focal person defined Improved building control regime initiated at the regional level Needs Assessment undertaken in some selected Governorates Reduced risks in local water supply and sanitation services in two pilot communities Technical know-how of vulnerable communities enhanced (if funded)

comment.narrative: These GOI lacks institutional capacity o deal with disaster risks management in Iraq Absence of disaster information and knowledge management at the national, regional and local levels Capacity gaps in Civil Defense on disaster emergency response Draft disaster law awaits enactment The stakeholders lack knowledge on existing sectorial good practices within Iraqi institutions on disaster risk reduction; Disaster Risk Reduction not integrated into sectorial development planning in a systematic manner The GECs lack legislative approval and suffer from limited capacities and mandate; Gaps exist in DRR awareness, knowledge and capacity at the Governorate levels Interests expressed by the vulnerable governorates and approached UNDP for local capacity building on DRR Drought, flood and earthquake incidents cause significant social, economic and environmental losses in Iraq; Poor understanding and practices on disaster preparedness and risk reduction at the community level Lack of capacities on early warning dissemination and community based disaster management

Technical assistance provided for establishment of the National DRR Center, including design, job descriptions, and details of requirements; National capacity and understanding on DRR/CCA enhanced Disaster Information and knowledge management unit designed and technical support provided for operationalizing the unit Focal points with defined roles and responsibilities on DRR established in the four sectoral ministries (agriculture, water resources, environment and education). DRR opportunities/entry points through existing UN projects mapped out Technical note on DRR Integration in four sectors developed. DRR training organized for the officials of relevant ministries/departments. Focal points with defined roles and responsibilities on DRR established in three vulnerable Governorates. Building safety promoted at the regional level Training for Governor officials and technical assistance for gender-sensitive disaster response and recovery Partnership initiated and DRR Focal point established in the selected municipalities and local communities. Disaster risks is addressed in local water management (two pilot communities) Training and exposure visits for enhanced knowledge and technical know-how (based on fund availability).

Partnership Strategy: The Project will promote partnerships at multiple levels. The Project will be implemented in close partnership between UNDP, UN agencies and development partners. The Project will facilitate strengthening of partnerships amongst government departments at national, governorate and local levels, and amongst government and non-government sectors; e.g. UN agencies, bilateral donors, NGOs etc. At the national level, the project will facilitate partnerships between the National Disaster Risk Management Center and the federal ministries, while it will also facilitate partnerships between the National DRM Center and the Governorates.

title.narrative: Signed Annual Workplan 2014 Asset Recovery and International Cooperation 88983
New Cover Page Signed by Sultan

description.narrative: Strengthened regulatory frameworks, institutions and processes in place for accountable transparent and participatory governance at national and local levels.
independent political entity

i. Asset recovery repository established.
ii. Asset recovery expert group established.
iii. Iraq specific ‘Country Guide Note’ on asset recovery developed.
iv. Series of workshops and consultations to enhance the role of civil society organization in asset recovery conducted.
v. A bill on asset recovery drafted.
vi. Regulatory framework developed. vii. The Anti-Corruption Academy training menu is expanded to include scientific training partnered with a University, short courses offered at intermediate and advanced levels and e-learning available.
viii. The oversight organizations established on-going dialogue and support from a sister, international specialized facility.
ix. Asset recovery tool promoted.

comment.narrative:
i. Asset recovery repository not in place.
ii. Asset recovery expert group not in place.
iii. Iraq does not have a ‘Country Guide Note’ on asset recovery.
iv. Civil society is not engaged in asset recovery
v. No bill exists on asset recovery.
vi. There is no regulatory framework in place for asset recovery.
vii. No training on asset recovery in place at the Anti-Corruption Academy.
viii. No Asset Recovery Centre in place
ix. No Asset Recovery tool identified.

1. Several working sessions were held with 15-23 CSOs to affect advocacy with the government, public interest groups and the media on the topic of asset recovery. These sessions resulted in developing mutual expectations and recommendations by CSOs and NGOs and government on asset recovery, and agreed the framework necessary for civil society engagement on asset recovery. This framework was developed further in the shape of establishing a ‘CSO Asset Recovery Guide’ a platform to enable CSOs to regulate their engagement with society and the government on Asset Recovery. The CSO’s Asset Recovery Guide contained the followings: Chapter One – The importance of recovering stolen assets. Chapter Two – The role of CSOs/NGOs in recovering stolen assets. Chapter Three – Nine detailed practical strategies on asset recovery for CSOs and NGOs; a. Raising public awareness. b. Advocacy. c. Establishing legal and regulatory framework. d. Monitoring and evaluation of asset recovery process. e. Tracing of stolen assets. f. Promoting declaration of income especially amongst politicians and political parties. g. Develop procedures for administering and managing confiscated assets. h. Mutual assistance. i. Managing and repatriation of stolen assets.
2. Technical assistance was provided through regular technical consultations in cooperation with the Asset Recovery Expert Group and experts on the subject for establishing regulatory framework on asset recovery detailing the integration and interaction amongst the different relevant entities (e.g. AMLU/CB, CoI, BSA, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Interior, ….. , etc.), this resulted in providing a comprehensive draft law on Asset Recovery for Iraq (see Annex 2).
3. Technical provision was provided through experts on Financial Intelligence framework in cooperation with national experts and practitioners in this field to establish procedures on asset recovery and international cooperation. Through several consultation se

title.narrative: Catalysing the Use of Solar Photovoltaic Energy

description.narrative: The objective of the project is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in Iraq by demonstrating and catalyzing the application of solar power to meet the energy needs of offices, small businesses, residences and town services

title.narrative: Endorsement for GEF project Catalysing the Use of Solar Photovoltaic Energy in Iraq

description.narrative: Investment in renewable energy application and policy reform
independent political entity

Megawatts of solar PV installed. Existence of RE policies and laws encouraging deployment. Existence of a clear set of regulations and technical and regulatory requirements for connecting to the grid. Volume of investments mobilised for solar PV power. Number of individuals and organisations capable of supporting activity in the Iraqi solar market. Records of PV market prices, participants and installed capacity to track development of solar PV in Iraq.

comment.narrative: There have been early-stage discussions between MoE and UNDP on net-metering. There have been no concrete steps or commitments. No effective capacity building exists for the industry. There are few industry players. No significant market data exist.

Installation and operation of 5 MW of distributed, grid-connected PV at Bytti. Installation and operation of 16 utility-scale PV plants. Monitoring and recording operational data from all Bytti and the 16 plants to inform the development of future PV plants. Development and implementation of a grid code for distribution and transmission (for small-scale distributed generation and larger utility-scale generation). Design and implementation of a process for IPPs to engage in standardized PPAs with the Ministry of Electricity, to acquire generation licences and to inter-connect with the grid. Development of model contracts for power purchase agreements. Implementation of phased fiscal incentives for PV uptake, including partial removal of import taxes on solar panels. Design of a feed-in tariff for renewable energy IPPs with appropriate pricing calibration, geographical zoning and regression schedule, and packaged as a NAMA. Evaluation of net-metering options for industrial and residential applications. Evaluation of a range of policies for specific circumstances, such as tenders for large solar installations (suitable for Iraq’s environment). Support to implementation of the feed-in tariff and/or net-metering scheme. Solar power market demand/industry response strategy developed for Iraq, informed by case studies from other countries with developed solar power industries, domestic market analysis, and clarification of Iraqi private sector opportunities for distributed solar PV power production. Iraq private sector and Government agencies exposed to all aspects of the industry (technology development, supply, servicing, financing). Development and delivery of certified technical training on solar PV technologies (hybridization, supply, service) for emerging private sector companies.
Mainstreaming environment and energy Catalysing environmental finance Promote climate change adaptation Expanding access to environmental and energy services for the poor.

description.narrative: To enhance basic public services by constructing community-based infrastructures and promoting the social cohesion between host communities and IDPs and creating short-term employment opportunities for the vulnerable populations in the affected areas
independent political entity
No. of community-based infrastructures project formulated through participatory community dialogues Increased accessibility of the key basic services

comment.narrative: 0 community-based project identified 0-10% of increased coverage of basic services
22 infrastructure rehabilitated/constructed Immediate employment opportunities provided to 1,600 heads of household

The project successfully enhanced provision of basic services, such as shelter, health, education, electricity, water and sanitation, to total of 11,444 households from the displaced and host community population, benefitting 57,220 individuals and provided access to livelihood opportunities for 3,920 households, beneficing 19,599 vulnerable individuals. Participatory dialogues process with 3,420 people in the communities where local population, IDPs, and Syrian refugees cohabits, promoted mutual understanding and social cohesion among them to reduce social tensions within the communities.

description.narrative: Iraq Crisis Response and Resilience Programme
Iraq Crisis Response and Resilience Programme
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Output 1: Existence of joint coordination mechanism at regional level. Existing emergency management cells at Dohuk level strengthened. Joint Coordination Committee is able to provide reliable data on the crisis and inform decision makers on gaps and response capacity as well as consolidated response plans.
Output 2: # of community restoration initiatives undertaken through partnerships between local authorities, community organizations, private sector entities, and amount of contributions provided by each of these. % of the above in which women’s organizations are directly involved. # of grievances established and % of grievances successfully redressed. # of community plans that are fed into the Governorate planning system. # of people (men/women) benefiting from improved access to socio-economic community infrastructure
Output 3: # livelihoods assessments are carried out and used to define project design options. # of men and women benefitting from cash for work (% of women). # of job opportunities created for vulnerable men and women through start up packages or vocational and business skills training.
Output 5: # of joint platforms established. # of ommon social cohesion analysis undertaken, based on community consultations. # of champions identified and engaged in consultation process. # of public opinion polls regarding social cohesion conducted.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Central coordination body exists in Baghdad but not at the regional level in Kurdistan.
Output 2: Existing emergency management cells at Dohuk level not strong enough.
Output 3: Insufficient community restoration initiatives undertaken through partnerships between local authorities, community organizations, private sector entities, and amount of contributions provided by each of these.
Output 4: No comprehensive data available on overall impact of crisis on livelihoods assets. Household coping mechanisms and livelihoods severly negatively impacted by crisis.
Output 5: No inter-community platforms established yet. No common social cohesion analysis available. No social cohesion champions identified in the target areas. No public opinion surveys on social cohesion carried out yet.

comment.narrative: JCMC and JCC have limited institutional capacity for information management, joint planning and response coordination within the GoI and with the international humanitarian actors

-Within one week after the trigger event of a crisis, real-time information become available on the crisis situations and the needs of the affected populations in the key humanitarian sectors, consolidating the information/data from JCMC/JCC, Fed/KR ministries and governarate emergency cells (by June 2016)
-At least 2 Crisis operation plans are formulated based on the accurate and real-time information/data provided by JCMC and/or JCC (by June 2016)

description.narrative: Enhanced Strategic Planning and Harmonizing Planning Process
Local Area Development EU
Accountability - local government finance

local development planning system in Iraq is neither systematic, nor institutionalized,o Overlaps in planning and wastage of resources, Gaps in planning ,lack of alignment and coherence of local plans , Planning is not consultative or inclusive.

comment.narrative: Lack of a coherent strategic framework for local planning , Lack of coordination and integration of planning processes , Poor service delivery and lack of client orientation, Additional stress on KRG service delivery due to influx of Syrian Refugees. Poor responsiveness of plans to local needs & lack of accountability to local communities, Weak capacity for planning, budget execution, monitoring and evaluation,

Improved capacity for planning and implementation at governorate level, resulting in higher budget execution and service delivery, leading towards better sector wide planning Baseline: Lack of a coherent strategic framework for local planning , Lack of coordination and integration of planning processes , Poor service delivery and lack of client orientation, Additional stress on KRG service delivery due to influx of Syrian Refugees Indicators: local development planning system in Iraq is neither systematic, nor institutionalized,o Overlaps in planning and wastage of resources, Gaps in planning ,lack of alignment and coherence of local plans , Planning is not consultative or inclusive, projects implemented at either sector or governorate level have Targets: Improve Governorate and Local-Level Sectoral Planning Capacities, Build Capacity of Federal- and Regional-level Ministries of Planning and affiliated Bodies to sustainably support the local development planning processes, Alignment of Governorate level plans with National Development Priorities and Goals, Alignment of Governorate level plans with National Development Priorities and Goals Support Outcome-based, Multi-Sectoral, Integrated Provincial Annual Development Plans linked to achieving National and MDG Priorities,Improve budget execution processes in sector line directorates and Governor’s offices Related CP Outcome: GoI has the institutional framework to develop and implement MDG-based pro-poor, equitable and inclusive socio-economic and environmental policies and strategies.

1- Launch of Strategic Provincial Plan for three KRG governorates Erbil, Sulemaniyah and Dohuk. 2- Workshop for Identifying the priorities and work plans 9 governorates. 3- Knowledge and good practice sharing and EU Covenant of Mayors workshop 4- 2 Needs assessments

title.narrative: Support to Security Sector Reform: Phase II

description.narrative: SSR Phase II will support the GoI in three main ways: 1- To implement the NSS as it relates to SSR 2- Strengthen democratic oversight of the security sector 3- Enhance civil engagement with the security sector

title.narrative: Support to Security Sector Reform: Phase II

description.narrative: Output 1: The GoI Plan for Security Sector Reform is developed. Output 2: The democratic oversight capacity of the SDC is strengthened. Output 3. GoI engagement with civil society in the field of SSR is increased.
Defence - policy, planning and administration

1.1 Indicator: SSR committee has an established platform mechanism and leads SSR discussions for both government and relevant external stakeholders 1.2 Indicator: GoI SSR Plan developed by the SSR Committee through extensive internal and external consultations 1.3 Indicator: SSR Committee has relevant capacity to design and conduct continuous internal assessments and mapping of the Iraq security sector 1.4 Indicator: Close engagement with provinces to build support of GoI SSR efforts and to ensure their inputs are considered within the SSR Plan 2.2 Indicator: SD Committee identifies potential parliaments with whom partnerships could be initiated in order to develop its capacity through peer-to-peer engagement and experience sharing with relevant institutions in other countries. 3.1 Indicator: Better overview of Iraqi civil society actors who could help the GoI in driving forward and advocating for the SSR agenda. 3.5 Indicator: ANCSS institutional and research capacity enhanced Strengthened capacity enables the ANCSS to contribute to policy development on security issues through provision of recommendations to the NSC

comment.narrative: 1.1 Baseline: SSR Committee established but lacking capacity 1.2 Baseline: Absence of existing GoI action plan for reform of the security sector in Iraq 1.3 Baseline: Absence of GoI capacity to conduct baseline assessments and mapping exercises of the Iraqi security sector and its existing capacities 1.4 Baseline:Few or no efforts to advocate for or to inform provincial government structures of activities related to reform of the Iraqi security sector 2.2 Baseline: Little to no engagement with other national parliaments in the field of defence and security. Suitable parliamentary partners have yet to be identified. 3.1 Baseline: Very few if any CSOs who specialise on issues related to SSR have been identified 3.5 Baseline: Al Nahrain Centre for Strategic Studies established but with weak institutional and research capacity . While the National Security Council (NSC) is the ANCSS’s primary client, they have received little to no contribution from the Centre to inform policy development on security issues as a result of limited capacity

1.1 The SSR Committee meets regularly and has held at least 5 consultations with government and non-government stakeholders to raise awareness of SSR and GoI efforts in this context 1.2 A first draft of the GoI SSR Plan is developed by SSR Committee with NSC oversight and consultation 1.3 SSR Committee conducts an initial assessment of the Iraqi security sector by September 2015 and is able to engage in a process of continual assessment. Results of assessment is used to inform the development of the SSR Plan 1.4 Establishment of mechanisms for the ONSA and the SSR Committee to regularly consult and coordinate with governorates on SSR 2.2 A series of consultations and roundtables are held for civil society and SD committee had have identified collaborative ways to coordinate on the design of the SSR plan and implementation. 3.1 By the end of 2015, the ONSA has identified and approached at least 15- 20 CSOs in Baghdad with whom they could engage on the issue of SSR. At least 50% of these will be women and youth groups. 3.5 Short-term/immediate priority institutional and operational needs have been assessed and identified in the ANCSS Action Plan with support from the UNDP expert. One event/initiative implemented by the ANCSS that provide policy recommendations to the NSC in the field of security

description.narrative: Protection, Empowerment and Recovery Support for the Syrian Refugees andn Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and Host Communities in Iraq
Enhanced Protection of IDPs women, girls and boys in Iraqi Governorates hosting a large number of IDPs
Defence - policy, planning and administration

1.1 Finalize design of Crisis24 Coordination Body with Kurdistan Regional Government 1.2 Set up regional level Crisis Coordination Body with the Kurdistan Regional Government 1.3 Provide technical advice and resources to the Regional Coordination Body in planning, monitoring and evaluation. 1.4 Develop capacity of coordination body to collect information and data including on environmental factors 1.5 Assess the capacity of the Emergency Management cells at the governorate level 1.6 Develop capacity development plans for the Emergency Management Cells 1.7 Assist the Emergency Management cells to collect information and statistics and develop recovery plans 1.8 Assist the Emergency Management cells to carry out coordination meetings 1.9 Assist the Ministry of Migration and Displacement in coordination as needed 1.10 Develop communication processes and reporting formats for monitoring the implementation progress within the Ministry of Migration and Displacement. 1.11 Review/ modernize current systems and procedures to support efficient and effective functionality of management cells (IPSM) 1.12 Review/ improve current administrative structures to support accountable and transparent responsiveness (IPSM) 1.11 Apply a contextualized version of the senior executive servicesystem to guarantee the appropriate selection of executives to manage the coordination body and develop dedicated training and development plans to nurture capacity and skills enhancement 1.12 Review, modernize current systems and procedures to support efficient and effective functionality of management cells (through IPSM) 1.13 Review/improve current administrative structures to support accountable and transparent responsiveness (through IPSM)

comment.narrative: Central coordination body exists in Baghdad but not at the regional level in Kurdistan. Target: Joint coordination committee set up at KRG level Emergency Management Cell or equivalent are set up in all governorates but do not have reliable information on all activities nor gap analysis or response plans 500 legal service cases achieved till July 2014

1- Establish joint platforms for discussion between the communities and the government to address concerns, share information and prioritize issues on human rights, ensuring active participation of women and youth 2- Strengthen Citizen Protection Departments of the Ministry of Family Affairs to process grievances and issues of the communities, ensuring particular focus on the most vulnerable 3- Strengthen Citizen Protection Departments of the Ministry of Family Affairs to process grievances and issues of the communities, ensuring particular focus on the most vulnerable 4- Project Management

description.narrative: Enhanced Protection of refugee women, girls and boys against S/GBV
Defence - policy, planning and administration

1.1 Existence of joint coordination mechanism at regional level. 1.2: Existing emergency management cells at Dohuk level strengthened 1.3 Joint Coordination Committee is able to provide reliable data on the crisis and inform decision makers on gaps and response capacity as well as consolidated response plans 1.4 Senior executives within the regional coordination body received dedicated skills enhancement support 1.5: emergency management cells are functioning in the governorates. 1.6 The staff of Parliamentary oversight unit have successfully completed the oversight training 1.7 The communication processes and reporting formats are developed and operational

comment.narrative: Central coordination body exists in Baghdad but not at the regional level in Kurdistan. Target: Joint coordination committee set up at KRG level Emergency Management Cell or equivalent are set up in all governorates but do not have reliable information on all activities nor gap analysis or response plans

Establish Vulnerability monitoring and legal aid centers with the Directorate of Combatting Violence Against Women or Family Protection Directorates on gender-based violence issues that can be accessed by the most vulnerable members of the communities, Refugees (namely the aged, widows, female heads of household, children, Persons With Disabilities (PWD), Minority Communities.

description.narrative: to quickly respond to emerging needs of the areas which were under ISIL control, this project is an addition to the LADP that supports the short and medium term stabilization and early recovery requirements within the longer term Local Area Development.

description.narrative: Number of stabilization infrastructural projects
